You can probably get access to all the content for free over time, but I decided to support the developers by purchasing in-game boosts & currency [as well as some of the 'buy' only ladies]... not that you need or have to, but even after pumping a silly amount of money into this title, I don't feel cheated... the writing and characters were worth it, IMO, even if the scenes are just a few frames.

Plenty of other H-games out there feel like a straight up money grab, and while the game does encourage you to spend money to speed up progress, its not hard-locked behind pay walls. Granted, there are plenty of extra and limited time ladies you have to spend money [or in game currency, "Diamonds"] on, but those are totally optional and there are 20+ ladies you unlock through regular game progression. You can also earn diamonds at higher relationship levels, so if you're willing to invest a boat load of time, you can play totally for free and still get boost from the Diamonds you earn... totally up to you.

The phone call/message aspect lends a refreshing take to an otherwise saturated genre, and also provides you with some nice pics to view at your leisure as you get further along in your "texting" relationships with the ladies in your phone book... my only gripe is having to be on a single conversation for it to continue progress [otherwise you get one message, go back, etc]... wish the ladies would just FINISH their convo and wait for your response, its an annoying progression-gate, devs!

All in all, a great ensemble of ladies from different genres and fetishes, all lovingly written and nearly all of them have actual voice-overs.

If you decide you're only going to spend a few bucks on the game, I highly suggest buying 'Catara' for her speed dating perk, it helps reduce quite a bit of clicky. You could also buy 'Suzu' for access to faster money-making early on, which can also help quite a bit.

(im not sure if it is or not) and the story is basic but gets the job done. you are a  humanoid marshmallow creature who is ether man or woman by default its set to male so that's what i went with (also im a man so there is that but the option is a pleasant one.) you meet Q-Pernikiss, a goddess of love looking for a vessel to fight back an evil being known as the The Dark One. and by fight i mean seduce her. ya see the way you become a "Pure Vessel for Q-Pernikiss is you must become so masterful of seducing woman to be able to seduce The Dark One. in the end the portal the dark one came through must be closed and only a pure body of love can close it doing so they must sacrifice then selves. ya see sense your a pure vessle of love and what not you fit the bill to close the portal so at the "end of the game" you have a choice to sacrifice yourself or Q-Pernikiss and then the world lives happy ever after good job. however the end isnt really the end ya see in order to complete the game there is a soft reset mechanic going on where you restart your progress with all the girls but your stats increase this stat is called a reset boost which increases the speed of which you do jobs, level up you hobbies, and how fast you can do dates and other stuff. as the rewind boost increases to a max of 2048 you get faster and better at everything so the replay ability is endless if you want to keep playing the game for the ending however i found this more repetitive than fun then again i found a glitch to increase speed on everything (for the developers i will describe how to do it later hopefully they fix this so they can milk all your diamonds out of you for things that the glitch bypasses) it got to the point of me doing 2 or 3 runs through the game a day and then i got burned out of it for the day. in all its a steady game with interesting mechanics that i thoroughly enjoyed

Cast
in crush crush you meet an assortment of characters ranging from the New York inspired sassy filled Cassie to gamer girl Mio to a BEAR named Bearvefrly yes a bear. and everyone in between the cast is very diverse and very well rounded being added to every couple of months or so with more DLC characters. this game is filled with personality and charm each character being more memorable than the last a full list of characters is available online if you wanna meet each girl and what they are about. HOWEVER some DLC characters are only available for a short period of time or are seasonal only so if you wanna meet each and every character dont get your hopes up at the time of posting i only have less than half the DLC characters and i just missed out on one of the limited time event characters from a part of the game called the phone flings more coming up soon on that. but its very frustrating running out of characters to go though which is sad sense they all add to your reset boost when you do a soft reset. without DLC characters i was getting about 150 reset boost on average around 1000 reset boost already collected however once i PURCHASED the DLC characters that were available on December 15 2021 it doubled to over 300 reset boost each run. 

The Phone Flings
a major part of the game is the phone flings. what is a phone fling i hear you ask well a phone fling is where you talk with ADULT woman over the phone which devolves to the girl texting you like 10 times you respond once with a 2 choice option which by my awareness dose nothing but a few changes in dialog until the girl sends you a risky photo and rinse and repeat 3 to 6 times per girl. now i may be sounding like the phone flings are a bad thing but to quite the opposite actually the phone flings have more character building than most of the girls in the main game and the cast of characters are just as stunning as the ones from the main game. some of which if you finish the phone flings give you a chance to purchase main game equivalents to them that continue on in the main game one of which and from my understanding is the only free one of these main game continues is Peanut. she is a collage girl you meet in the phone flings that is continued in the main game. there are plenty of characters in the phone flings that make an appearance in the main portion of the game however catching them when they are available is no easy task your options are whatever the devs decide on whats avalable at that time. which is not very fun if ya ask me if i had my way id make all the characters avalable but at increased prices and have the ones you want to sell more of go on sale but that's just me. oh and dont worry a sofr reset will not reset your phone flings in any way other than the ability to start ones if a certain criteria is met an example i had was if you needed a hobby at a certain level and you got it up to that level and didnt click on the character even though you met the criteria if you do a soft reset you will loose the ability to play that character if you dont click on the character untill you meet the requirement again\

the DLC

I'm the kind of gamer who doesn't trust free games.  Because seldom, of course, are they really free.  And why should they be?  People gotta eat.  Yet I still much prefer to know what I'm paying for up front than to get bled to death with the slow, tempting allure of in-app microtransactions.

So let's just get this out of the way: if you're the kind of person without a lot of either disposable income [i]or[/i] patience, don't get this game (assuming you haven't already learned this lesson with one waifu gacha game or another).  But if you're up for the challenge of balancing a small purchase here or there with a healthy dose of delayed-gratification conditioning, you could certainly do worse than Crush Crush.

Conceptually, Crush Crush is a simple idle game.  You meet girls, work jobs, practice skills, and earn money over time (real time).   The money can be used to purchase gifts for your ever-growing harem, allowing you to attain higher and higher relationship levels with them, which in turn leads to unlocking more girls, jobs, and skills.  You also earn diamonds from advancing with different girls, which are the [i]real[/i] currency in this game, allowing you to purchase things from the store (like time skips, speed boosts, and additional characters), and can also be used to substitute for the in-game money you earn from working jobs.  Of course, extra diamonds (generally) cost extra money.  And if you want to speed things up, you can soft-reset the game for a faster track back to your current spot and beyond - the speed boosts are permanent and you can soft-reset as many times as you like.

What really stands out with Crush Crush is the production values.  First and foremost are the characters.  Rather than being the usual hentai cutouts, they're engaging, well-written, nicely drawn (save for a few serious cases of anime bug-eyes), and exquisitely voice-acted.  With self-conscious humor, smart cultural references, and (generally) non-gratuitous sex appeal, they put girls from other idle games like "Booty Calls" to shame, and you'll likely find one or two CC girls which you desperately wish were real (sigh ... Peanut ...).  And the great thing is that the Panda team is constantly adding new ones, and finding new ways to do it - most recently with the addition of "Phone Flings", where you "text" with the girls instead of "talking" with them, and they send you naughty sex-pix in return.  And on a couple of occasions now they've held fan votes to write PF girls into the main game as datable characters.  Overall, it shows a lot of commitment and care by this team, which is how a good idle game should be (what with them being the cash-cows that they are).

Of course, you don't have to go broke playing this game - so long as you are willing to wait and spend your money wisely.  Diamonds come from reaching new relationship levels with different girls and by direct purchase in the store, but you can earn one or sometimes three each day by logging in and hitting a one hour counter (you have to remember to come back later to claim your prize, though).  (Incidentally, this is also how you get access to the additional girls beyond the base set, which generally require a login every night for two weeks to hit a one-second counter that lets you immediately claim credit without coming back later.)  As performing soft-resets is a big part of the game, you'll want to avoid spending your diamonds on things which don't persist through a reset, like gifts or time skips (as opposed to, say, speed bursts or extra time blocks).

Once you finally make it all the way with a given girl, you're rewarded with a still-photo sex "scene", which you can replay later on at will.  It's reasonably satisfying, but the real fun is in the journey, just listening to the interesting lines you'll get as each relationship progresses, and seeing how each girl reacts to "tickle attacks".  Overall, it's a rewarding experience - and that's saying something in an oversaturated niche of mediocre cash-sinks.

This game is, in simplified terms, similar to many dating sims. There are over twenty individual girls to "woo", all having certain requirements to progress your relationship with them.

Pros

● Unlike many dating sims, this offers nearly full vocal dialogue.

● Has hobbies to train your skills, such as motivation, wisdom, lucky, and nine more, giving a sense of time needed to improve.

● Ability to work multiple job and train hobbies at the same time.

● Can reset the game to increse the speed at which stats, jobs or relationships level up.

● Free to play, but gives the option to buy diamonds, a special in game currency, if you want to.

Cons

● Once you get to higher levels in your relationship, stats, or jobs, it takes much longer to level up(six hours to level up a skill from 44 to 45 at the fastest multiplier for speed increase).

● The game gives you a cap on the number of actions you can do at one time, dependent on the number of available "time blocks" you have, and the cost of these actions. Later on you need to train multiple skills at the same time to progress to certain points in the game. If you don't have a lot of time blocks, training those AND working jobs can be impossible, meaning you may have to switch back and forth.

● Can be considered similar to a freemium game. Meaning it's free to play, but you have to pay to progress quicker. Again, quicker, not quickly.


Conclusion

If you don't mind the pay to progress aspect OR the much slower leveling, you will enjoy this game. If this style of gaming is not for you or you don't like the concepts I listed, I recommend looking for a different game.

How should I put it... this game is actually like one of those Facebook "waiting game" and a clicker game cleverly disguised as a dating sim. When you actually have the game opened, your time will be spent getting the required criteria to "level up" your relationship with a girl. When you run out of money or lack the skill level to further improve relationships, you'll need to earn (in-game) money and train your skills, which happen in real time. Therefore, you can either leave the game idle or just close the game with the meters running; you'll reap the rewards the next time you open the game.

So here's the thing: while I said it's a cleverly disguised dating sim, it is not, in fact, a dating sim. That's because your ultimate goal is to max out the relationship with all the available girls, so you don't really make any important choices like picking one girl over the other. There are no negative choices you can make that will ruin your relationship with any girl, no quizzes with right and wrong answers. It's just a grind from start to finish, rinse and repeat kind of game. Probably the only things you do in this game are clicking on the girls for hearts [spoiler](which is something easily accomplished with an auto-clicker software)[/spoiler] and planning your activities efficiently, the latter which gets stale late game when you have more than enough time blocks.

The plus side about this gem is that it has a somewhat nice art style. That, and the girls' not-so-subtle reference to modern pop culture. You have your standard line-up of a [i]tsundere[/i], a gamer girl, and a "cosplaying" cat girl, but there are also girls who are also right out of other genres ([b]SPOILERS![/b]: [spoiler]Ayano is from the Yandere Simulator game, Iro is a reference to Rainbow Dash from the My Little Pony: Friendship Is Magic cartoon[/spoiler], etc.) so if you're a modern day geek like me, you'd give the game points just for those.

Idle Games all follow the same pattern. You have resources (time), you allocate these resources to gather goods (money or hobby levels), you use goods to gather more resources (more time blocks). You hit a ceiling at some point in which more resources cannot be obtained; then you "reset" and in the next incarnation certain benefits take place (prestige bonus) that allow you to break through the previous ceiling.

This category of game is very little about gaming, and more about managing resources and achievement hunting. Usually the premise doesn't play any role, but CrushCrush tries to shine in its market by offering the "dating simulator" premise (which is VERY questionable), kawaii waifus and a very, very, VERY pink interface. But by far the most attractive point of CrushCrush is the fact that it is "F2P". Quotes intended.

As I said, the premise doesn't matter for this kind of game, but it has its touch of humour at some points which is a plus. The art is okay, awkward sometimes. What kills it - beware my friends - is the fact that there is a limit in "resetting". And it is not of the reasonable kind.

After the obtaining the modest 2048 multiplier, your resets give you no further benefit and by all means there is not a reason to reset anymore. Alternatively... you can keep going further by affording Speed Boosts in the "$$$ Store <3". Of f***ing course. Let me give you an idea of [i]how bad[/i] it is, shall I? So if you spend, let's say, 10$-ish and get a x64 Speed Bonus, you'll have a 2048x64 multiplier. Having in mind the wooping 2048x8192 multiplier, it doesn't take a genious to realize that Speed Bonuses are [i]absolutely necessary[/i] for this game. As a F2P you can afford some of these Speed Boosts with bonuses you get along the game, but nowhere near the 8192. Sadly, I did buy the bonus at the beginning before I realized that this game was unreasonably unbalanced.

Don't go on trying to defend the game devs by throwing the "it is supposed to last forever!!" kind of cards. According to the maths in the official forums, a F2P player would need, after obtaining the maximum Prestige and free Speed Bonus, 2 years to unlock the last two girls. I am not talking about two years of fun, dedication and love. I am talking about two years of [i]not playing the game[/i], because there is absolutely [i]nothing[/i] more to do there, other than [i]waiting two bloody years[/i]. Even for a game that it is [b]*not*[/b] about gaming, this has crossed the line between the "lulz" and the "wth? O.o"

Advice to the devs: tune your game down, Karma and Sutra are unreasonable. It takes about a week for someone with MAXED stats to get Golden Slippers. I'd wait a week if your game had something else to offer during this week, but when instead it literally tells me "forget me, come back next week" I might as well not come back at all. Lift the Prestige Bonus Limit, or at least raise it. A Lot. Add more girls in between Karma and Luna to help F2P to farm Diamonds for Speed Boosts.

Also, personal advice: this game is hosted somewhere else, a website which has been rumoured to scam customers with "fake drop ratios" for some of the other games they host. I have witnessed some of it myself and ever since never logged back.
